title: YouGov poll shows 84% of Brits and 63% of Americans want Anne Sacoolas to face UK justice
text:
Ann Sacoolas (pictured), 42, is alleged to have knocked Harry Dunn, 19, off his motorbike near her husband's workplace at RAF Croughton in August

The vast majority of Britons and Americans want a US diplomat's wife stripped of her immunity after she was allegedly involved in the death of a teenage motorcyclist, a new poll claims.

Anne Sacoolas, 42, is thought to have knocked Harry Dunn, 19, off his motorbike near her husband's workplace at RAF Croughton in August.

She applied for diplomatic immunity through his job and returned to the USA without having to face any legal action.

But a new poll has revealed 84 per cent of Britons and 63 per cent of Americans believe her diplomatic immunity should be revoked and she should face justice over the allegations.

Prime Minister Boris Johnson has urged the US State Department to reconsider its decision and said he will raise the issue with the White House.

It was revealed yesterday Mrs Sacoolas was fined in Virginia back in 2006 for 'failure to pay full time and attention' while driving.

She was fined £200 for the offence, which usually concerns drivers caught making phone calls while driving, but traffic lane discipline is also commonly linked with the charge.

After the mother-of-three was named, Mr Dunn's grieving parents have demanded to speak to her.

His mother Charlotte Charles said this week: 'If we have to, we will go to ­Washington. We just want to sit and talk with her.

After the mother-of-three was named as being linked to Harry Dunn's death (pictured right), his grieving parents (mother Charlotte Charles pictured left) have demanded to speak to her

A new YouGov poll has revealed 84 per cent of Britons and 63 per cent of Americans believe her diplomatic immunity should be revoked and she should face justice over the allegations

Mr Dunn was struck near to her Mrs Sacoolas' husband's workplace, RAF Croughton, where US intelligence employees are based

'We don’t ­understand how you can just get on a plane and leave behind the devastation she has without even speaking to us or facing us, or an apology of any kind.'

Ms Charles also claims Mrs Sacoolas was driving on the wrong side of the road when her son Harry was hit on August 27.

He was struck near to her husband's workplace, RAF Croughton, where US intelligence employees are based.

The US Embassy in London said it would not comment on the identity of the driver who allegedly hit Mr Dunn yesterday.

A spokesperson said that requests to strip diplomatic immunity garner 'attention at senior levels' but admitted that it is rare to waive immunity.

The YouGov poll was carried out yesterday, involving 1,611 UK adults and 2,584 from the USA.
